topic.title: Down the Rabbit Hole We Go...
topic.body: Wonder how many groups can be nested inside each other... If it's infinite, that's scary.

1565261539_19P54y9K3sV4nbe7Cm3yCZfuwxzck.body:
Just exploring ZeroNet as a new user, seeing how it works, and how to implement and contribute to its network.
That and playing Elite Dangerous at 04:00AM when I have to head to work nine hours from now...

> [theosis](#comment_29_149W17bFN1NbQou6iE81Uq2b8wEvyqwUV1): How is E:D right now? I used to play it a lot when it was released.  [...]

Not bad. I stick to solo play, due to current peer-to-peer mechanics of the game enabling multiplayer shenaniganry, like that Beluga in the mailslot (see https://youtu.be/2jkP7d9j07Y for the story). All in all, it's a nice way to unwind after a long day. Haven't achieved Elite rank in anything yet, but I'm playing it for the enjoyment of it rather than aiming for goals. :)

1565330250_18h7dSc5vXQNRA1sjyUmX7zaUTsFA.body:
> [wejehteman](#comment_2_1EJorU3nHcCViXXzD7BkmyJzwgqxqC2Zuv): ...could be an attack where if a botnet shows up with 9000 peers, and your computer connects to 200 of them, then chances are that all 200 connections are the botnet. Then the botnet simply doesn't send you new updates.

While I have little to no experience with ZeroNet, this sounds strangely plausible. Yikes.

1565330984_1EFZ3dYDWVpD4kF5H9PF83HjPAehE.body: That is hilarious. Have an updoot.

1565354906_1GFU4qAMTFnQJ7W7r98Zj2xJWq1ev.body:
> [joebagel](#comment_1_1BF8Uak9sNrxmgyaVYa1waLwe98CG8ogpB): The article itself - https://archive.fo/4vAKm [...]

Just me, or is https://archive.fo unreachable?

> [theosis](#comment_41_149W17bFN1NbQou6iE81Uq2b8wEvyqwUV1): Most of 8ch people are poltards and retarded boomers who believe in this Qanon nonsence. Not exactly the brightest when it comes to tech.

Ehh, I'm not a boomer, but I am pretty new to this.
I went ahead and enabled "Tor: Always" almost immediately after starting.
Am I doing it right? >.<

> [capitanjack](#comment_5_1DNJ1b7d7bqeZHigy35ZKBwwe8PBv8o7Gk): If you are afraid of (((them))), but its not way of doing it. There is fear prison first.Once you get out of it, switch Tor just to enabled and help improving network by normal p2p connectionsYou can always use VPN as bridge so your ISP eventually wont call you.I hate those sort of phones :^)

Yeah, I do want to contribute to the network; I've increased the size limit on a few promising zites.
Though, as for VPNs, I don't really trust third-party stuff like PIA/etc...
I only really use a personal VPN to my home router to prevent sniffing of traffic by local network peers at public access points, like at Starbucks, or the public library.

> [theosis](#comment_42_149W17bFN1NbQou6iE81Uq2b8wEvyqwUV1): The thing is, you can go ahead and use it even without Tor. If you're not doing anything illegal you have nothing to worry about. The fact that your IP is exposed to peers means nothing. They can't reliably connect your ZN identity to your peer IP. It's not illegal to run ZN software. This "muh exposed IP" scare is silly.

Awesomesauce. I just kinda enabled it on a whim, since I was (relatively) familiar with onion routing's benefits.

> [capitanjack](#comment_6_1DNJ1b7d7bqeZHigy35ZKBwwe8PBv8o7Gk): To be honest on imageboards that might happens very often.

I kinda assumed that'd eventually happen, which played a part in me enabling it, since while I do want to help seed boards, having to moderate what I seed seemed like a pain. (Gah, run-on sentences.)

1565358798_1CKTRBy9N4RvE3FgeZJpQqFYtLHc3.body:
I'm... not certain what exactly you're trying to say here... Could you clarify a bit?
Being completely honest here: this post sounds like it was made by an AI.

> [tinktinktink](#comment_15_15QMtSMe3Ckgr3m3bajRgDbNsChibX6sK4): He has been posting this retarded crap nonstop on the this website's 08ch thread.Just mute him.

Ah, hokeydokes.
Wasn't sure if it was a bot, or the incoherent musings of someone whose primary language isn't English. ^u^

> [h3bhkj5gqz4n3pjm](#comment_693_1CKTRBy9N4RvE3FgeZJpQqFYtLHc37yo11): don't you have an identity on zeronet ?"trevorlanera"

Yep. I just started playing around with ZeroNet out of curiosity earlier today.
Went ahead and created a certificate for my personal use while I learn about it.

Ohhh, I think I see what you were getting at.
The centralization of an identity generation system, right? You mean ZeroID?

> [h3bhkj5gqz4n3pjm](#comment_696_1CKTRBy9N4RvE3FgeZJpQqFYtLHc37yo11): obviously

Gotcha. Was thinking you were talking about the philosophy of identity or something. Sorry.
But yeah, I suppose using ZeroID as a central identification is a bit wonky.
I'd have to learn more about how ZeroID works...
From what I understand thus far about it, it's an optional system that zites can implement for purposes of identity.
Correct me if I'm wrong. :P

> [xcape2net](#comment_193_1GJc2vm4vJjAKsFoFJ2D3gGmKiRac2kfnz):  If @nofish dies or disappears, I think that ZeroNet would disappear--not really sure at this point.
Also, each Zite is owned by someone who has to be able to stop others from modifying their zite.
Also, there is the bit-torrent tracker issue.  ZeroNet requires bit-torrent trackers to function.
Then there is ZeroID centralization.
The bottom line for me is that ZeroNet is a combination of centralized and decentralized software.

Gotcha. Thanks for the clarifications. :)
Aaaand I completely misunderstood how to format a reply's quote text. XD

> [xcape2net](#comment_194_1GJc2vm4vJjAKsFoFJ2D3gGmKiRac2kfnz): ...you have a 50K limit for posts and comments on ZeroTalk, right?  If @nofish decides not to increase your limit, you are silenced.

Wait, what? By 50K, do you mean KB of info, 50K characters, 50K posts?

> [xcape2net](#comment_195_1GJc2vm4vJjAKsFoFJ2D3gGmKiRac2kfnz): A lot of new users get caught by this.  I did.  I mean that you can type 50 kilobytes of text into ZeroTalk before you reach your limit.  Then, or preferably before you hit the limit, you have to email @nofish to get it raised.  How much you have already used is displayed opposite the "Submit comment" button.  See it?

Ooooh, holy moly. I just glanced over that, assuming it was a character count limit like with Twitter.
Yikes.
Then again, all the more reason to keep my posts concise. :D

> [xcape2net](#comment_196_1GJc2vm4vJjAKsFoFJ2D3gGmKiRac2kfnz): Exactly.  Although, I think @nofish is very lenient.  He hasn't kicked off the OP, yet.  So, I think almost everyone is safe.

Good to hear.
On a side note, though... When I click "Reply," that quoted text counts towards my limit, doesn't it?
Should I make it a practice to trim down quoted text to the relevant parts?

> [xcape2net](#comment_198_1GJc2vm4vJjAKsFoFJ2D3gGmKiRac2kfnz): I believe so, but I'm not sure.

Ah, yep. Just tested; quoting text does indeed count towards the limit.
Makes sense though. Exempting quoted text would both create a loophole to bypass the limit and/or increase system load parsing quoted text to differentiate it from OC.

> [qf2ss4t5y3365](#comment_14_1Nvii56FXr3CYjLPscUya4UutDqnMKjK1B): No, you just make a new ID. Why the hell would you bother him to raise your limit? This isn't twitter... No blue checkmarks here.

That's... hmm. Good point. Not sure how @nofish would feel about this becoming the norm.

> [h3bhkj5gqz4n3pjm](#comment_705_1CKTRBy9N4RvE3FgeZJpQqFYtLHc37yo11): you all talk like zombies like you 'didn't know the answers',sometimes it's funny to see you all 'articulte things'. it reminds me years before 'trying not to see the obvious'.

I think people didn't understand what you meant initially about users having individual identities versus users all utilizing a singular identity.
Kind of like... mmm... I guess the best way to put it would be analogous to the ending of Neon Genesis Evangelion: basically a singularity of identity.
Everyone basically using a singular identity as a single entity. As if all posts were by the same person.

> [randomshits](#comment_33_1CuFETj5LtyEduzaoAcdv9sMAQtYRqjqDY): Most who know a discussion will be extensive will often carry or link it over to Unlimit Talk which has a vastly increased posting size. [...]

Is Unlimit Talk considered the #2 place following ZeroTalk?

> [randomshits](#comment_35_1CuFETj5LtyEduzaoAcdv9sMAQtYRqjqDY): No, it is nowhere nearly as popular as ZeroTalk.But if you post a link on the ZeroTalk article saying "Continue the discussion Here", most people comply

Gotcha. Good to know; I'll add that to my seeded sites then. :)

> [qf2ss4t5y3365](#comment_15_1Nvii56FXr3CYjLPscUya4UutDqnMKjK1B): they had a psychotic meltdown and started passionately making out with their monitor.

The mental image of that just gave me the giggles.

> [223556](#comment_60_1LdgxNSynzpd5Vyi3Ej12adEuWbo1nWFu9): schizos lmao

Ohh, be nice, you.

> [xcape2net](#comment_206_1GJc2vm4vJjAKsFoFJ2D3gGmKiRac2kfnz): It's comments like that that have me leaning toward AI.  But maybe you're just playing me.

Ah, and now I've got the giggles again.
Seriously though, I think it's just that he's either not a native English speaker, or just has difficulty with vocalizing what he means.

> [h3bhkj5gqz4n3pjm](#comment_713_1CKTRBy9N4RvE3FgeZJpQqFYtLHc37yo11): read more, ancient texts, the response 'are in them'. intelligent people of ancient civilizations 'wrote them', not God. these people 'were all above the intellect', so no i'm not playing with you.

Hmm. I think I understand how your vernacular works now.
Kind of like how my inner thoughts work; they're more conceptual than verbal constructions.
Like how Bumblebee from Transformers speaks, using ideas (encapsulated in soundclips) rather than words.

> [kaffie](#comment_937_1NWh3WAty57FH8at1WtrZigMrdhrDkuPzh): Just to be clear, schizophrenia can impair your use of language, making you sound like you're a non-native speaker. Likewise with the weird phrasing, rants seemingly disconnected from everything, etc. It's bizarre falling down that rabbit hole but still maintaining some sanity.

Good point. I've been trying my darndest to decipher u/h3bhkj5gqz4n3pjm's posts, and respond constructively. :P

> [h3bhkj5gqz4n3pjm](#comment_717_1CKTRBy9N4RvE3FgeZJpQqFYtLHc37yo11): it means you can and actually function at mutliple levels, intellect being 'one of them'. this body 'is way more complex than people think it is'.

You mean like Carl Jung's "Shadow?"

> [h3bhkj5gqz4n3pjm](#comment_719_1CKTRBy9N4RvE3FgeZJpQqFYtLHc37yo11): you can 'understand me' but not with the center you're actualling('most of the times') using:https://experiencelife.com/article/healthy-gut-healthy-brain/

Heh, I dunno if the "healthy gut" was the right comparison to make, but yeah, I get you. :)

> [h3bhkj5gqz4n3pjm](#comment_720_1CKTRBy9N4RvE3FgeZJpQqFYtLHc37yo11): the gut is the right center, cerebral death don't imply death

Ahh, by center you meant hemisphere, by which you meant the abstract thought/conceptual part of the psyche.
I gotcha.

> [h3bhkj5gqz4n3pjm](#comment_721_1CKTRBy9N4RvE3FgeZJpQqFYtLHc37yo11): the images are in the brain, transcription then memorized in it,but the gut is an independant organ, with 'its own reasoning'.

Yep yep. I was just initially confused when you said "healthy gut," and assumed you meant something to do with the gastrointestinal microfauna biome. XD
Was gonna say, my e-coli aren't that sentient. :P

> [xcape2net](#comment_215_1GJc2vm4vJjAKsFoFJ2D3gGmKiRac2kfnz): And the two are connected by a nerve (which I forget the name of), which is why I feel afraid when I'm nauseous.

Mmm, the vagus nerve?

> [xcape2net](#comment_216_1GJc2vm4vJjAKsFoFJ2D3gGmKiRac2kfnz): Yes.  Thanks.

High school biology comes into play at the weirdest times... :/

> [peppermintswirl](#comment_6_123mMiSRJ2T5wrMtS9Ub8rKvPTRcTjVSTx): https://i.ibb.co/XbdkfHp/unknown.pngConfirmed not a bot, but still hella schizo

Oooh, that's an interesting tool. Seems like something that'd be neat as a browser extension.

> [qf2ss4t5y3365](#comment_18_1Nvii56FXr3CYjLPscUya4UutDqnMKjK1B): I FOUND IT. Sylvaine was his name and I even found the kopykate post. http://127.0.0.1:43110/big.kopykate.bit/?Video=1521868593_1F9qtxgSgbkeJX7NT2BARwR8XCn1XP4qPG

That was an interesting watch.
Kudos to the creator for putting the effort into it.

1565457554_1A5NgDyiTqhcBgrm8SuSEhaygTXuc.body: Very well... Just for kicks 'n giggles.
Heh, it's a link to the original Shibe (doge) image on ZeroVoat.

1565466571_18YwqjZF3kZjfbWcsvyfzzL8okGn2.body:
> [ayra](#comment_2_15Pwu5qSwuLDbQeJPixgirchJGHcHw4ioT): ROM files hosted inside a weird folder structure on a GoDaddy server that advertises a camera lens. Why do I get the feeling that the owner of this website has no idea that the files are there.

Might be a hijacked site, or perhaps its obscurity as a photography site is to throw off copyright notices.
However, I'm confused by the assortment of games in the GBA archive; there's none of the Pokemon games (Ruby, Sapphire, Emerald, FireRed, LeafGreen, etc).
Something in the back of my mind is telling me this is an attempt to expose ZeroNet user IPs.

> [ayra](#comment_3_15Pwu5qSwuLDbQeJPixgirchJGHcHw4ioT): Doing illegal things (publishing roms) to get a few IP addresses sounds stupid. Especially because there's a button that copies all IPs of participating members of a site to the clipboard.

Mmm. Good point. Though I don't know enough about ZeroNet yet to dispute that the button actually exposes real addresses of tor-only users.
I'm just weirded out by the relative disparity with most popular packs of ROMs; so many of the most popular ROMs aren't included...
Just doesn't feel right... ^u^

> [steeljacket](#comment_6_18YwqjZF3kZjfbWcsvyfzzL8okGn2DRW1a): Hey can we uuencode shit here? Can you post the popular pokemon ones?

I'd probably just DL them from a clearnet torrent, then reseed them on ZeroUp, then post the ZeroUp link.

1565575545_1KUSKrffaR1sfLwxZUXUPshLpKhh5.body:
ABC
It's easy as 123.
As simple as do re mi.
Baby, P2P.

1565577175_18YwqjZF3kZjfbWcsvyfzzL8okGn2.body:
Heh, this gave me a chuckle.
To be honest, I'd like a verified tag myself, if just for kicks 'n giggles.

But you raise a good point... How would one go about establishing a "verified" tag on a decentralized platform?
From what I understand, the concept of a "verified" identity is based on a centralized authority (Facebook/Twitter/etc) granting recognition that an online identity is who they claim to be in real life.
That "verification" is reliant on the trustworthiness and reputation of the central, verifying authority.

On a decentralized platform, this is nigh impossible, without a central authority to recognize an identity as "you."
I suppose the closest you could come to "verification" here is to somehow sign your ZeroNet identity with a private key, and post the public key to a post on an external, central authority like Twitter.
Basically, using a "verified" account on something like Twitter to claim that your ZeroNet identity is indeed you.

...I dunno. I'm rambling; I'm no expert when it comes to cryptography, nor cyber philosophy.

> [brianhanson2nd](#comment_36_1N8yx3zC1YKuam31pUi9eQUruBCEF9u3eE): ...cuckbook and twatter.

That's that. Renaming my bookmark for Twitter to "Twatter." :D

1565649984_1PPUrYcZ1E1rGkkE6PH18Qi43LRsK.body:
> [styromaniac](#comment_971_16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRFtVBhd): We don't need scaredy-normies anyway.

> [mg0](#comment_93_1LbP2cNA6NkvuFJvs7McUmv9qGjkNqVkTa): Don't be like that, we need all the people until we got many enough.

While I understand how styro feels, mg0 is correct; we need as many peers as we can get to strengthen ZeroNet's infrastructure.

1565819093_1J6JfEeFfwmkogEHaMgs8MohbzpzM.body:

Ahh, I see.
I saw them as glyphs because I was using Tor browser. Switched over to Chrome, and they display properly. :D

Ah, good walkthrough.
Thanks for making the time to post this.

_sigh..._

Hmm. Good point. Will have to make better use of each post, instead of making new ones to correct myself.

1565951931_16VcDM9UrXq4VY2MAKJhfuiN1DoG5.body:
> [unadu](#comment_23_16tiWQCvXDH6r8GWNGUzvvnAHqN89eX72W): ...you could move/delete the data/users.json file in the zeronet folder. This file holds your IDs. If its gone, you can create new IDs.

Hmm...
Is there a way to correctly edit the users.json file to manually delete/add your identities?
(Like, is there any documentation on the layout & formatting of the users.json file?)
I mean, if so, I'd like to understand how, then write an AutoHotKey script GUI to parse users.json and allow management of identities.
This way, I could avoid resorting to cookies (blegh) for identity management.
If I were to enable the multiuser plugin, I'm assuming this would effectively replace the functionality of the users.json file. Once I do, wouldn't this mean I'd have a difficult time porting those cookies back into the users.json file?
Cookies aren't exactly the way I'd like to manage identities, since they're easily (irrevocably) deleted during common cleaning tasks (i.e.: CCleaner & etc).

> [littlepaw](#comment_4_16VcDM9UrXq4VY2MAKJhfuiN1DoG5ktAD3): I have managed to remove the unneeded identities just by editing the users.json file you mentioned. [...]

Wait, if the multiuser plugin uses cookies to manage identities, does it export identities from users.json to cookies, but not use the users.json file once you start using it?
Or does it keep users.json file up-to-date with the cookie-based identities you create and manage?

> [littlepaw](#comment_5_16VcDM9UrXq4VY2MAKJhfuiN1DoG5ktAD3): ...One would hope it keeps the users.json updated, but that may not be the case...

Hmm. I'll have to test this.
I'll back up users.json, then start with a blank users.json.
Then I'll enable the multiuser plugin.
Then, I'll try creating a new identity with the multiuser plugin as the identity manager.
I could then diff the changes between a brand new (blank-ish) users.json, and the version of it after identites have been created with multiuser.
This should, in theory, show if the multiuser plugin actually acts as a bridge between the cookie-based identities, and the users.json file, updating users.json when there are new identities created.
Can't hurt to experiment, right? :P

> [unadu](#comment_25_16tiWQCvXDH6r8GWNGUzvvnAHqN89eX72W): ...it ignored the identities from users.json completely and didn't update it.
> [gitcenter](#comment_569_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2nK5Di): What Multiuser plugin does is create several identities in users.json.

... I'm so confused right now. ^u^

> [unadu](#comment_26_16tiWQCvXDH6r8GWNGUzvvnAHqN89eX72W): well, my experience... was that i lost all identities and that it wouldn't remember them and that i couldn't even turn off the plugin...

Oof. Yikes.
Sounds like I'm better off just writing an AHK script for simple GUI management of identities in users.json.

> [littlepaw](#comment_6_16VcDM9UrXq4VY2MAKJhfuiN1DoG5ktAD3): ...what does the "u" in ^u^ mean? Is it the mouth or the nose?

Honestly, I've no idea. Probably just an obscure uwu/owo'ism; I always assumed it was a smile. :P

> [gitcenter](#comment_571_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2nK5Di): Multiuser plugin was made for ZeroNet profixes (e.g.: zn.amorgan.xyz)
Wait, what's a profix? Like, a prefix? To what? (Sorry I'm such a noob...)
> [gitcenter](#comment_571_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2nK5Di): I believe nofish is currently working on making a simplier UI for user management.
This is great to hear! Though... I do wish there was documentation on the layout & formatting of users.json.
If I knew more about it, it'd make writing this script easier...

> [unadu](#comment_27_16tiWQCvXDH6r8GWNGUzvvnAHqN89eX72W): ...it does make sense that a plugin that uses cookies would not work very well if you don't save cookies.
Yeah, especially with the Tor browser being the recommended browser to use with ZeroNet...

> [gitcenter](#comment_573_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2nK5Di): That was a typo, sorry; I meant to say a "proxy".
Ohhhh. Gotcha.

> [gitcenter](#comment_579_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2nK5Di): ZeroNet just generates them randomly; but I wouldn't recommend deleting them, for example, you should backup auth_address and auth_privatekey on ZeroID site if you have a ZeroID registered.
Solid info; good to know.
I was thinking about parsing through the "sites" section to focus on just those fields, allowing for per-site identity management. I'm guessing the rest of each site's section is just site-specific preferences like themes/etc.

Trying to piece together what functionality I want to implement in my GUI script. What I've got in mind so far:
- Certificate identity management. (The keys in the "certs" section.)
- Site-specific identity management. (Allowing for deletion of site **auth_address** and **auth_privatekey** if associated with main certificate identity. That is, deleting a site's **auth_address** and **auth_privatekey** if the identity used on that site is deleted.)
- Management of site preferences. (Allowing you to clear a site's customizations, but keep identities used on it.)

I'm really just kind of dicking around with it for kicks 'n giggles. :P

> [gitcenter](#comment_580_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2nK5Di): Sounds great! I'd like to use that.
I'll post a public copy of the script's source code on [NullPaste](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1MgHVPCE1ve6QfKrgsqCURzRj72HrRWioz) once I put the finishing touches on it.
It'll be interesting to see others' edits & takes on the idea of a users.json-based ID management.

1565922890_16tiWQCvXDH6r8GWNGUzvvnAHqN89.body:
> [joalmo](#comment_25_15ZG53yDqMJyxRy3jfkC4NGeKapAC5CDrL): (((science agrees)))You're talking about sociology, which is not really science.
Ehhh, I dunno. Science is a method of thought. A way of approaching an idea and testing ideas.
Socio**logy**, essentially the "study of society," can be approached in a scientific method.
I guess you mean to say that studying society & social aspects isn't a science in and of itself, per se?
I can understand that viewpoint.
I'd be confused if you said that social structures can't be studied in a scientific method. :D

1565922993_16YKCPxCUyjP3zF1CNtsWCHu44Toa.body:
> [rusnoob1](#comment_19_1CyoFuqywpEgKYPHjQUui3TJQuEDqNqThN): Why?
Well, it's not really feasible to moderate threads, other than preventing your node from propagating troll/spam posts.
One person can't claim authoritative power over a thread to silence posts.
That being the case, we can't do much to keep threads civil & organized.
This group, being named "Normie Safe Space," is likely to attract the kind of attention & activity it strives to avoid.

> [xcape2net](#comment_316_1GJc2vm4vJjAKsFoFJ2D3gGmKiRac2kfnz): Correct me if I'm wrong, but my understanding is that the person who cloned the zite can delete anything they like.
I know comparatively nothing about ZeroNet's technical side, but from what I've garnered, it seems like all downloaded viewed/stored content is permanently clientside until the client deletes it.
**Don't get me wrong, I could be totally incorrect here.** I just have a hard time believing such a great decentralized platform would allow such a hierarchical vulnerability as a tyrannical zite cloner deleting their zite's contents, effectively remotely deleting content from seeders' nodes.
It would completely neuter the very idea it strives to accomplish...
I mean, sure, individuals could simply clone a zite for archival purposes as a contingency for if a zite's clone owner went bananas and started censoring other users' content posted to it.
*sigh*... I dunno. I'll have to read into the documentation a bit more. I'm still a total noob to this.

> [xcape2net](#comment_317_1GJc2vm4vJjAKsFoFJ2D3gGmKiRac2kfnz): There have been several discussions here where people are concerned that nofish has too much control of ZeroNet because it is more centralized than it first appears.
Saw those discussions earlier, and went back to read through them again. Seems you're right...

If this isn't the case, then yeah... that's pretty worrying. ~_~

> [ytkhgf](#comment_3_1GmeqFDH3CreaouRZZeg3WuC3JY1mRmXmr): Israel's government-sponsored Yad Vashem Holocaust Memorial Center started putting Amazon under pressure to remove any and all material that questions the orthodox Holocaust narrative."
Hmm. Not sure how I feel about a government-backed organization pushing to censor the views and ideas of others, regardless of how reprehensible they may be.
I mean, yeah, I completely understand YVHMC's feelings toward this kind of material; it'd certainly be offensive to them. And Amazon, being a private company, is certainly within their right to choose the material available on their platform.
The documents' authors are completely within their right to voice their views, so long as it's not crossing into illegal territory (calls to violence/etc).
Mragh. This kind of shenaniganry is beyond my wherewithal to even debate.
While it's probably not something I should even waste my time reading, I would like to know that such viewpoints are able to be at least heard by those that are interested in analyzing those ideas. Freedom of speech and whatnot.

1565966684_1HnEYBLwyqrym7tJhQgrdyRGQ2W1d.body:
Whoof. Lots of good advice in there, on a cursory glance.
Personally however, while I am a ProtonMail user, I'm still hesitant to use ProtonVPN.
Still, ProtonVPN is indeed a better option than most VPN providers.

> [ploplesuper](#comment_2_1HnEYBLwyqrym7tJhQgrdyRGQ2W1dkJMsD): Basically, as i know,  the two best VPN are NordVPN and ProtonVPN i use the second one !
Mmm. If I ever were to use a VPN (I usually don't), ProtonVPN would be my first choice.
I've seen some pretty convincing anecdotal evidence that NordVPN/PIA and the like actually cave to government pressure. I'd be way more comfortable rolling with a VPN provider that takes the unequivocal stance of protecting its users at any cost. (Similar to Lavabit's admirable actions back in 2013.)

> [ploplesuper](#comment_3_1HnEYBLwyqrym7tJhQgrdyRGQ2W1dkJMsD): ...with a few contributions from the communities it could become very powerful for free speech.
Indeed. Looks pretty promising. I actually wanted to contribute to the IPFS party, but wasn't experienced enough in the ancillary security practices to tighten it down for security and long-term data integrity.
Maybe someday in the future I'll hop on the bandwagon, but for now, the plug-and-play ease of ZeroNet's deployment has me hooked.
Though, I'm somewhat concerned about fragmentation of decentralized systems' implementation in the long run.
With so many different ways of going about it, it's hard to decide on which one to use on a daily basis.
Perhaps if each system were more purpose-oriented, it'd make sense for each system to use it's own framework.
But with so many systems sharing common functionalities (boards/chans/etc), it's likely  to end up with the same issue that streaming services face (Netflix/Hulu/HBO Now/etc). If too many start competing with each other for the same userbase's desired functions, it effectively divides that userbase into semi-centralized bubbles.
Hate for the ecosystem to head in the direction of having to crosspost between platforms... XD

> [ploplesuper](#comment_4_1HnEYBLwyqrym7tJhQgrdyRGQ2W1dkJMsD): Actually BlockChan plan to implement a research toolbar.
Oooh, that's good to hear.

> [xlk](#comment_64_1PA19ZVGt9k6GEX2mYAF6w5zJCPYKWaJEp): What the hell is this, ProtonVPN propaganda? I feel I'm being sold a time-share!
Heh, I feel ya. We are kinda coming across as shills for their VPN service.
That being said, their mission statement and stance on privacy is pretty commendable.
I will say, however, ProtonMail does still have some issues. (Javascript for clientside encryption is still served up by ProtonMail servers, and thus cannot be trusted.)
They've still got a long way to go with the work on their services, but all in all, I've no reason (yet) not to trust their promise to protect their userbase.

> [xlk](#comment_65_1PA19ZVGt9k6GEX2mYAF6w5zJCPYKWaJEp): ...I suspect you are a federal agent, journalist, or some other person that is here in an official capacity.
Ahhhh, god, I've got the giggles again. Yeah, no, I'm just a script-kiddy computer enthusiast.
> [xlk](#comment_65_1PA19ZVGt9k6GEX2mYAF6w5zJCPYKWaJEp): ...the types of comments one would make if they knew they were to be subject to review.
Yeah, to be fair, I'm a bit careful with what I say online. Not only to keep things civil in an otherwise unmoderateable platform, but also because clarity and conciseness helps to keep the dialectics of discussions from being derailed by misunderstandings.
That, and I'm a bit of a grammar freak. Albeit not an expert on English etymology, and nearly failing high school English class due to a late essay, I did pay attention when it came to writing/sentence structure/etc. You probably know those textbooks on how to write a narrative (introduction, rising action, climax, resolution, etc). I halfheartedly skimmed through them, but it seems they've stuck with me.
(It's a bit tough sometimes though, because some users have a mental difficulty with putting ideas into words. I actually encountered a user earlier that phrased things in... I dunno, more of a conceptual manner, rather than a cohesive, understandable structure. It kinda forces you into a heuristically disjointed thought process, in order to decode what they mean to say. In many cases, it's just the case that English isn't their main language. After conversing with that kind of person for a while, I find myself having to switch mental gears back to regular thinking.)

> [ploplesuper](#comment_5_1HnEYBLwyqrym7tJhQgrdyRGQ2W1dkJMsD): Completly forgot that this kind of decentralized topics is full of Paranoaic folks :D
Heh, that may be the case, but a certain measure of paranoia is good. Can't hurt to be careful.
That being said, just take care not to go full tinfoil-hat; it's not healthy to stress oneself out over stuff that's not in your threat model. <3

> [xlk](#comment_66_1PA19ZVGt9k6GEX2mYAF6w5zJCPYKWaJEp): That's pretty trusting; putting all of your personal information out there like that.
Yeahhh, I'm probably not following best practices having that up.
I was really just toying around with VPS hosting and webserver management/web design.
I initially tried doing a PHP based site, but found static HTML5 was more my speed.
Someday I'll actually use a personal mail server, but I'm taking it in baby steps.
EDIT: Edited it to only show my hometown, and added my ZeroMail address to the contact method list. :P

> [h3bhkj5gqz4n3pjm](#comment_766_1CKTRBy9N4RvE3FgeZJpQqFYtLHc37yo11): ...people should study more this reality which is very different that what it is taught.

> [myriri](#comment_38_145qVnMUHFaHhDNmmd1s2ZPh5FTArtZmjn): So would these cameras be fucked by IR LEDs? I recall that being a good trick to deal with ubiquitous surveillance.
Only to the point that most optical sensors usually don't have a good range of adjusting exposure for directed bright IR (albeit "intensity" would be more apropos, since "brightness" _usually_ refers to EMR in the visible spectrum).
Silicon-based CMOS and CCD sensors can pick up on radiation into the near-infrared.
In order for a RING camera to be able to see at night with no visible light, it has to use IR-emitting LEDs to illuminate the area, and pick up on that infrared light with its sensor.
Basically, in order for a CMOS/CCD sensor to be impervious to aforementioned methods of surveillance blocking, it would have to make itself blind at night, by blocking LED-emitted IR wavelengths.
If I were to theoretically manufacture a day/night security camera, I'd want it to be able to switch to UV as an alternate illumination method if it detected overexposure in one of those wavelengths.
But then that could be circumvented by someone using _both_ IR and UV LEDs, forcing the design of the camera to resort to triggering porch lights or something as a last-ditch effort to illuminate the area to properly capture footage.

TL;DR: Yes. To be completely sure, outfitting oneself with high-intensity IR/UV LEDs would be a viable method of blinding a camera without damaging it. Lasers can blind cameras as well, however, **I do not recommend doing so**, since they can actually permanently damage the CMOS/CCD sensor, and you could be held liable for property damage if used.

> [myriri](#comment_39_145qVnMUHFaHhDNmmd1s2ZPh5FTArtZmjn): Not tried this in years so unsure if it still works.
I'd go for nothing less than a full 360° array of LEDs to be safe.
Thinking more on it, I wonder if the IR emission of the camera's own LEDs could be used against it by employing retroreflectors. Probably not... would be interesting to test.

> [myriri](#comment_40_145qVnMUHFaHhDNmmd1s2ZPh5FTArtZmjn): ...fitted onto an american style baseball cap.
Hmm. There's an abundance of caps that have regular old LED lights on the rim for lighting the area in front of you at night... Could be easy to replace those LEDs with IR ones, and even add more, keeping most of the built-in circuitry, then upgrading the battery to power the array in parallel so as to handle the extra load. :D

> [myriri](#comment_41_145qVnMUHFaHhDNmmd1s2ZPh5FTArtZmjn): They tend to mount them under the brim of the hat making it a bit less useful in this context.
Yeah, that's true...
Meh. While being a fun DIY project, it'd probably just be easier to go for RING camera's true weakness: Wi-Fi jammers and deauthers if you wanted to avoid being surveilled entirely (i.e.: stopping the video recording from around the corner before crossing its line of sight). Of course, this would be pointless if the camera makers thought to implement a local cache of footage for cases like this.
But I digress; jamming radio frequencies and using deauthors is considered illegal, so it's not really a good option.

> [myriri](#comment_42_145qVnMUHFaHhDNmmd1s2ZPh5FTArtZmjn): Ehhh de-authers are a legal grey area to some extent.
That's... hmm. I guess so. I mean, it's not "jamming" per se, but actual data signals.
Might see new legislation on the practice in the near future, seeing how proliferous they've become.
(See [Maltronics](https://maltronics.com)' lineup of devices.)

> [zhetik](#comment_6_1LPwiAHM9fBUSUR5iQNVizdVMniKhC11ju): The police called me last night and want me to come over to the station. I THINK IT'S A TRAP!!!
Probably is not a trap, per se, but more likely a scam.
Find your local police department's phone number, and check with them to see if the person that called you is part of their department.

In any case, try to cooperate, but *don't forget* that you have the undeniable right to maintain silence.
You don't *have* to answer any of their questions; you have the right to not self-incriminate.
If you do visit the police department, do so only for the purpose of finding out why you were called there.
If you're not being detained, you have the right to leave at any time.
Before you leave, bring a written copy of your Miranda rights, and read over it. You need to be familiar with them.

In the vast majority of cases, police are there to protect and serve.
Give them the benefit of the doubt, and that respect will be reciprocated. :)
